comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Interesting histories of the 'Sobraon' - www.gunplot.net/colonialnavy/hmastingira1.htm and www.navyhistory.org.au/the-history-of-hmas-tingira/ (2 pages).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
14 years later the Sobraon cadets used their swimming skills to demonstrate the self-righting design of the life boat the Alice Rawson, launched at Cockatoo Island. See Don Shearman's recent additions to his family album -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5466920826/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5466321343/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5469041851/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for posting those links to the history of the Sobraon. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Great photos, thanks for including them. Other Sobraon related info can be found on our Kieran Gallery - the story of Barney Kieran, Championn Swimmer of the World. He took up swimming when he was sent to the Sobraon industrial school and reformatory at the age of 13. AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The sad end of a great ship (as usual I was searching for something else) - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/5321668722/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is an early (Feb 1871) photo of the 'Sobraon' at west Circular Quay in her days as a "tea clipper" - www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] An oft-reproduced photo that one. The Mitchell Library has a higher quality version online - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=414349

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Henry King photo possibly showing the 'Sobraon' 'Vernon' (white stripe on side) moored off Cockatoo Island, with a corner of these baths at bottom left (before that pale screen thing was built?) - from.ph/30861

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The Henry King photo you linked to must be 1870s or 1880s as there appear to be ships moored in Snails Bay behind Birchgrove house and according to this book the bay was filled in from about 1883 to form Birchgrove Oval. I think the photo of Birchgrove Park in the book is printed backwards as Birchgrove House should be on the left from that angle.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] By my not-very-scientific reckoning with GoogleMapsSatellite, a line from Cockatoo Island through Birchgrove House site (near the bend in Louisa Road) misses most of the reclaimed area of Snails Bay, so I am not too sure about your theory - most of the Henry King photos seem to be c.1888.

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content:
I think both the State Records and the Powerhouse photos are taken from the south east part of Cockatoo, in the case of the Powerhouse photo from the cliff above Fitzroy Dock. I'm basing this on the angle of view of Louisa Rd and the the assumption that the stone wall in the Powerhouse photo is the same as the one in 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5466351119/]

If that's the case, the masts to the right of Birchgrove House would have to be in what is now the park I think.
